verses.text: My son, if you have put up security for your neighbor, if you have struck hands in pledge for another,

rsbNotes.title: Pr 6:1
rsbNotes.text: 6:1 pledge for a stranger. Such an agreement to guarantee another’s debt is unwise because it involves matters quite beyond the guarantor’s control (11:15; 17:18; 22:26).

verses.text: if you have been trapped by what you said, ensnared by the words of your mouth,

rsbNotes.title: Pr 6:2
rsbNotes.text: 6:2 snared. Borrowing money is one thing, but to provide security for another is to walk into a trap of one’s own making.

verses.text: then do this, my son, to free yourself, since you have fallen into your neighbor's hands: Go and humble yourself; press your plea with your neighbor!

rsbNotes.title: Pr 6:3
rsbNotes.text:
6:3 into the hand. By accepting responsibility for another’s debts you allow another to take control of your life.

hasten. See text note. This is not the time for pride.

verses.text: Allow no sleep to your eyes, no slumber to your eyelids.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 6:4
rsbNotes.text: 6:4 Give your eyes no sleep. There must be an unremitting effort to have the contract annulled.

verses.text: Free yourself, like a gazelle from the hand of the hunter, like a bird from the snare of the fowler.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 6:5
rsbNotes.text: 6:5 The imagery of creatures hunted and trapped heightens the sense of urgency.
